text: Ukraine participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2017. In addition to participating in the contest, the Ukrainian broadcaster National Television Company of Ukraine (NTU) also hosted the Eurovision Song Contest at the International Exhibition Centre in Kyiv after winning the competition in with the song "1944" performed by Jamala. The Ukrainian entry for the 2017 contest was selected through a national final, which NTU organised in collaboration with the commercial broadcaster STB. == Background == Prior to the 2017 Contest, Ukraine had participated in the Eurovision Song Contest thirteen times since its first entry in . The nation had won the contest on two occasions: in with the song "Wild Dances" performed by Ruslana and in with the song "1944" performed by Jamala. Following the introduction of semi-finals for the , Ukraine had managed to qualify to the final in every contest they participated in thus far. Ukraine had been the runner-up in the contest on two occasions: in with the song "Dancing Lasha Tumbai" performed by Verka Serduchka and in with the song "Shady Lady" performed by Ani Lorak. Ukraine's least successful result had been 19th place, which they achieved during the , with the song "Razom nas bahato" performed by GreenJolly. The Ukrainian national broadcaster, National Television Company of Ukraine (NTU), broadcasts the event within Ukraine and organises the selection process for the nation's entry. In the past, NTU had alternated between both internal selections and national finals in order to select the Ukrainian entry. Between 2011 and 2014, NTU had set up national finals with several artists to choose both the song and performer to compete at Eurovision for Ukraine, with both the public and a panel of jury members involved in the selection. NTU withdrew from the contest for one year in due to the unstable financial and political situation caused by the conflict in east Ukraine. In 2016, NTU collaborated with the commercial broadcaster STB in order to organise a national final to select Ukraine's entry, resulting in the selection of an entry that went on to win the Eurovision Song Contest. NTU's collaboration with STB continued in 2017. ==Before Eurovision== === National final === The Ukrainian national final took place in February 2017 in Kyiv. The selection was a joint production between the Ukrainian national broadcaster NTU and commercial broadcaster STB. All shows in the competition were hosted by Serhiy Prytula and broadcast on both UA:Pershyi and STB. ====Online wildcard selection==== Applicants had the option of entering their entry into an online wildcard selection which accepted entries between 1 September 2016 and 10 January 2017. The entries were published online at STB's official website and users were able to cast one vote per day. While at first the entry with the highest number of votes qualified to compete directly in the final of the competition, the entry picked, Deep Shivers by KUZNETSOV, was instead placed into the second semifinal. : Qualification to the semi-final {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! colspan="5" |Top-10 |- ! City !! Artist !! Song (English translation)!! Votes ! Place |-style="font-weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | Kyiv | Kuznetsov | "Deep Shivers" | align="center" | 11,820 | align="center" | 1 |- | Kyiv | Denis Povaliy | "Written On Your Heart" | align="center" | 10,311 | align="center" | 2 |- | Kyiv | Katya Syvun | "Pryvyd" (Ghost) | align="center" | 2,479 | align="center" | 3 |- | Kharkiv | Legenda Folium | "My Space" | align="center" | 2,199 | align="center" | 4 |- | Lutsk | One Light Inside | "Stay" | align="center" | 1,920 | align="center" | 5 |- | Kryvyi Rih | Kseniya Popova | "Let it Fall" | align="center" | 1,919 | align="center" | 6 |- | Kyiv |Litvinkovich | "Nasha Liybov" (Our Love) | align="center" | 1,375 | align="center" | 7 |- | Kyiv | Alex Angel & Lady Gala | "Running For Love" | align="center" | 1,296 | align="center" | 8 |- | Ivano- Frankivsk | Nataliya Pylyponyuk & Dzhoan Sereso | "Serenada Ukrayini" (Serenade Ukraine) | align="center" | 1,293 | align="center" | 9 |- | Kryvyi Rih | Oksana Pryimak | "Za Krai" (Over the Edge) | align="center" | 1,077 |align="center"| 10 |} ====Format==== The selection of the competing entries for the national final and ultimately the Ukrainian Eurovision entry took place over three stages. In the first stage, artists and songwriters have the opportunity to apply for the competition either through an online application form or by attending a scheduled audition during designated dates. Applicants also had the option of entering an online wildcard selection, the winner of which gained direct entry into the competition's final show. The second stage consisted of three televised semi-finals that were held in February 2017, which featured eight to twelve acts competing in each show. Two to three acts were selected to advance from each semi-final based on the 50/50 combination of votes from a public televote and an expert jury. The third stage was the final on 25 February 2017 and featured the eight to 12 qualifying acts from the semi-finals and the winner of the online wildcard selection. The overall winning entry was determined via the 50/50 combination of votes from a public televote and an expert jury. The expert jury that voted during the shows consisted of: *Konstantin Meladze – Composer and producer *Jamala – singer- songwriter, winner of the Eurovision Song Contest 2016 for Ukraine *Andriy Danylko – comedian and singer, represented Ukraine in 2007 as the drag artist Verka Serduchka ====Competing entries==== Artists and composers had the opportunity to submit their entries via an online submission form which accepted entries between 1 September 2016 and 15 January 2017. Alternatively, interested performers were able to attend live auditions that were held in the six major cities of Ukraine: Zaporizhia, Kharkiv, Odessa, Lviv, Dnipro and Kyiv. Composer and producer Konstantin Meladze was assigned as the music producer of the show for the second consecutive year and lead in reviewing the received submissions and shortlisting entries to compete in the national final. 23 entries were selected to compete in the national final. The names of the qualifying entries were revealed on 17 January 2017. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Artist ! Song (English translation) ! (Oh, mom!) | Ivan Klimenko |- | SKAI | "All My Love For You" | Oleh Sobchuk, John Hill |- | Tayanna | "I Love You" | Max Barskih, Tetiana Reshetniak |- | Vitaly Kozlovsky | "I'm Your Light" | Dima Bananov, Maryna Skomorokhova |- | Vivienne Mort | "Iniy" (Frost) | Daniela Zayushkina |} ====Shows==== ===== Semi-final 1 ===== The first semi-final took place on 4 February 2017. The top two entries following the combination of votes from a public televote and an expert jury advanced to the final of the competition, while the remaining six entries were eliminated. "I Love You" performed by Tayanna and "O, mamo!" performed by Salto Nazad were the qualifiers. In addition to the performances of the competing entries, 2017 Belarusian Eurovision entrant Naviband and 2017 Georgian Eurovision entrant Tako Gachechiladze performed the 2017 Belarusian entry "Historyja majho žyccia" and Georgian entry "Keep the Faith" as a guest. Naviband also performed a Belarusian version of the winning song "1944" by Jamala. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text- align:center;" |- ! colspan="8" |Semi-final 1 – 4 February 2017 |- !rowspan="2"| Draw !rowspan="2"| Artist !rowspan="2"| Song !rowspan="2"| Jury !colspan="2" class="unsortable"| Televote !rowspan="2"| Total !rowspan="2"| Place |- !Percentage !Points |- | 1 |align="left"| SKAI |align="left"| "All My Love For You" | 6 |9.54% | 5 | 11 | 4 |- | 2 |align="left"| Roman Veremeychik & Lumiere |align="left"| "Make It Real" | 2 |6.30% | 3 | 5 | 6 |- | 3 |align="left"| Monochromea |align="left"| "Blue Bird" | 3 |4.35% | 2 | 5 | 7 |- | 4 |align="left"| Laliko |align="left"| "Sugar Whisper" | 1 |4.29% | 1 | 2 | 8 |-style="font-weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | 5 |align="left"| Salto Nazad |align="left"| "O, mamo!" | 8 |11.82% | 6 | 14 | 2 |- | 6 |align="left"| MamaRika |align="left"| "We Are One" | 5 |8.76% | 4 | 9 | 5 |-style="font- weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | 7 |align="left"| Tayanna |align="left"| "I Love You" | 7 |30.05% | 8 | 15 | 1 |- | 8 |align="left"| Arsen Mirzoyan |align="left"| "Geraldine" | 4 |24.90% | 7 | 11 | 3 |} ===== Semi-final 2 ===== The second semi-final took place on 11 February 2017. The top two entries following the combination of votes from a public televote and an expert jury advanced to the final of the competition, while the remaining six entries were eliminated. "Saturn" performed by Rozhden and "Thank You for My Way" performed by Illaria were the qualifiers. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="8" |Semi- final 2 – 11 February 2017 |- !rowspan="2"| Draw !rowspan="2"| Artist !rowspan="2"| Song !rowspan="2"| Jury !colspan="2" class="unsortable"| Televote !rowspan="2"| Total !rowspan="2"| Place |- !Percentage !Points |- | 1 |align="left"| Letay |align="left"| "Svit chekaye" | 1 | 5.76% | 1 | 2 | 8 |- | 2 |align="left"| Mila Nytych |align="left"| "Mystery" | 3 | 7.66% | 3 | 6 | 7 |- | 3 |align="left"| Kuznetsov |align="left"| "Deep Shivers" | 2 | 18.08% | 7 | 9 | 5 |- | 4 |align="left"| Aghiazma |align="left"| "Synthetic Sun" | 5 | 7.66% | 2 | 7 | 6 |- | 5 |align="left"| Detach |align="left"| "Distance" | 4 | 17.71% | 6 | 10 | 3 |-style="font-weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | 6 |align="left"| Rozhden |align="left"| "Saturn" | 8 | 11.18% | 5 | 13 | 2 |- | 7 |align="left"| Panivalkova |align="left"| "Dokuchayu" | 6 | 10.37% | 4 | 10 | 4 |-style="font-weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | 8 |align="left"| Illaria |align="left"| "Thank You for My Way" | 7 | 21.59% | 8 | 15 | 1 |} ===== Semi- final 3 ===== The third semi-final took place on 18 February 2017. The top two entries following the combination of votes from a public televote and an expert jury advanced to the final of the competition, while the remaining six entries were eliminated. "Time" performed by O.Torvald and "Wonder" performed by Mélovin were the qualifiers. In addition to the performances of the competing entries, 2017 Spanish Eurovision entrant Manel Navarro performed the 2017 Spanish entry "Do It for Your Lover" as a guest. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="8" |Semi-final 3 – 18 February 2017 |- !rowspan="2"| Draw !rowspan="2"| Artist !rowspan="2"| Song !rowspan="2"| Jury !colspan="2" class="unsortable"| Televote !rowspan="2"| Total !rowspan="2"| Place |- !Percentage !Points |- | 1 |align="left"| Payushchie Trusy |align="left"| "Singing Pants" | 2 | 3.48% | 1 | 3 | 8 |-style="font-weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | 2 |align="left"| O.Torvald |align="left"| "Time" | 7 | 19.70% | 7 | 14 | 1 |- | 3 |align="left"| Anastasia Prudius |align="left"| "Flow" | 3 | 7.71% | 3 | 6 | 6 |- | 4 |align="left"| Vitaly Kozlovsky |align="left"| "I'm Your Light" | 1 | 5.27% | 2 | 3 | 7 |- | 5 |align="left"| Kadnay |align="left"| "Freedom In My Mind" | 8 | 14.50% | 5 | 13 | 3 |-style="font-weight:bold; background:#FFDEAD;" | 6 |align="left"| Mélovin |align="left"| "Wonder" | 5 | 23.84% | 8 | 13 | 2 |- | 7 |align="left"| Green Grey |align="left"| "Future Is On" | 4 | 10.15% | 4 | 8 | 5 |- | 8 |align="left"| Vivienne Mort |align="left"| "Iniy" | 6 | 15.36% | 6 | 12 | 4 |} ===== Final ===== Final takes place on 25 February 2017. Special guests of the Final Show are Alma and Kasia Moś. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="9" |Final – 25 February 2017 |- !rowspan="2"| Draw !rowspan="2"| Artist !rowspan="2"| Song !rowspan="2"| Jury ! colspan="3" |Televote (SMS) / App !rowspan="2"| Total !rowspan="2"| Place |- !Votes !Percentage !Points |- | 1 |align="left"| Salto Nazad |align="left"| "O, mamo!" | 1 | 21,978 | 11.35% | 3 | 4 | 6 |- | 2 |align="left"| Mélovin |align="left"| "Wonder" | 2 | 60,455 | 31.22% | 6 | 8 | 3 |-style="font-weight:bold; background:gold;" | 3 |align="left"| O.Torvald |align="left"| "Time" | 5 | 49,514 | 25.57% | 5 | 10 | 1 |- | 4 |align="left"| Illaria |align="left"| "Thank You for My Way" | 4 | 14,388 | 7.43% | 1 | 5 | 5 |- | 5 |align="left"| Tayanna |align="left"| "I Love You" | 6 | 32,319 | 16.69% | 4 | 10 | 2 |- | 6 |align="left"| Rozhden |align="left"| "Saturn" | 3 | 14,968 | 7.73% | 2 | 5 | 4 |} == At Eurovision == The Eurovision Song Contest 2017 took place at the International Exhibition Centre in Kyiv, Ukraine and consisted of two semi-finals on 9 and 11 May and the final on 13 May 2017. All countries except the "Big 5" (France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom) and the host country, are required to qualify from one of two semi-finals in order to compete for the final; the top ten countries from each semi-final progress to the final. As the host country, Ukraine automatically qualifies to compete in the final. In addition to their participation in the final, Ukraine is also required to broadcast and vote in the second semi-final. The European Broadcasting Union (EBU) split up the competing countries into six different pots based on voting patterns from previous contests, with countries with favourable voting histories put into the same pot. On 25 January 2016, a special allocation draw was held which placed each country into one of the two semi-finals, as well as which half of the show they would perform in. {| class="wikitable" |-
